content.title: Echocardiography
content.summary: Echocardiography is the most widely used cardiac imaging modality, utilizing ultrasound waves to assess cardiac structure, function, hemodynamics, and valvular pathology in real-time. It encompasses transthoracic (TTE), transesophageal (TEE), stress, and intracardiac approaches.
key_points: TTE is first-line for most cardiac evaluations; TEE provides superior visualization of posterior structures
Left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) is assessed by Simpson's biplane method or visual estimation
Doppler echocardiography enables assessment of valvular stenosis/regurgitation severity and hemodynamics
Strain imaging (speckle tracking) detects subclinical myocardial dysfunction before EF decline
Stress echocardiography detects inducible ischemia and assesses valvular response to exercise
Point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) provides rapid bedside cardiac assessment in emergencies
content.statement: Echocardiography is the cornerstone of cardiac imaging, providing real-time assessment of chamber size and function, valvular structure and hemodynamics, pericardial disease, and intracardiac masses. Its portability, lack of radiation, and comprehensive hemodynamic data make it indispensable in cardiovascular medicine.

explanation.intuition: Ultrasound waves are transmitted through chest wall tissues and reflected at tissue interfaces. The timing and intensity of returning echoes create images. Moving blood cells cause Doppler frequency shifts proportional to flow velocity, enabling hemodynamic calculations.
explanation.key_insight: The combination of 2D imaging, M-mode, and Doppler (pulsed-wave, continuous-wave, color flow, tissue Doppler) provides comprehensive structural and hemodynamic assessment. Each modality has specific strengths: CW Doppler for high velocities, TDI for diastolic function.
explanation.technical_details: Standard TTE includes parasternal long and short axis, apical 4/3/2-chamber, and subcostal views. LVEF by Simpson's biplane traces endocardial borders at end-diastole and end-systole in apical 4 and 2-chamber views. Valve gradients use modified Bernoulli equation: ΔP = 4V².

definitions_glossary.transthoracic_echocardiography: Standard cardiac ultrasound performed through chest wall acoustic windows
definitions_glossary.transesophageal_echocardiography: Echo probe positioned in esophagus for superior visualization of posterior cardiac structures
definitions_glossary.ejection_fraction: Percentage of blood ejected from left ventricle each beat: (EDV-ESV)/EDV × 100%
definitions_glossary.simpsons_biplane_method: Volumetric method summing discs traced from apical 4 and 2-chamber views for accurate EF
definitions_glossary.pulsed_wave_doppler: Velocity measurement at specific sample volume location, limited by Nyquist (aliasing)
definitions_glossary.continuous_wave_doppler: Measures highest velocity along entire beam path, no aliasing limit
definitions_glossary.color_flow_doppler: Color-coded visualization of blood flow direction and velocity across 2D image
definitions_glossary.tissue_doppler_imaging: Measures myocardial tissue velocities for diastolic function assessment (e'/a' ratio)
definitions_glossary.strain_imaging: Speckle tracking echocardiography measuring myocardial deformation, sensitive for subclinical dysfunction
definitions_glossary.global_longitudinal_strain: GLS measures overall LV myocardial shortening, normal >-18%, impaired if less negative
definitions_glossary.diastolic_function: Assessment of LV relaxation and filling using E/A ratio, E/e', and TRV
definitions_glossary.stress_echocardiography: Echo performed during exercise or pharmacologic stress (dobutamine) to detect ischemia

pathophysiology.mechanism: Piezoelectric crystals in the transducer convert electrical signals to ultrasound waves (2-5 MHz for cardiac imaging) and vice versa. Reflected echoes create images. Doppler effect measures blood and tissue velocities based on frequency shift of returning echoes.
key_pathways: Ultrasound transmission through acoustic windows (intercostal spaces)
Reflection at tissue interfaces with different acoustic impedance
Doppler frequency shift proportional to blood/tissue velocity
Digital signal processing for image reconstruction
pathophysiology.clinical_significance: Enables comprehensive non-invasive cardiac assessment in real-time, guiding diagnosis and management of heart failure, valvular disease, cardiomyopathies, pericardial disease, and acute cardiac emergencies.

standard_measurements.diastolic_function: Grade I (impaired relaxation): E/A<0.8; Grade II (pseudonormal): E/A 0.8-2; Grade III (restrictive): E/A>2

valve_assessment.aortic_stenosis: Severe: AVA <1.0 cm², mean gradient >40 mmHg, peak velocity >4 m/s
valve_assessment.mitral_regurgitation: Severe: EROA ≥0.4 cm², regurgitant volume ≥60 mL, vena contracta ≥7mm
valve_assessment.aortic_regurgitation: Severe: PHT <200ms, vena contracta >6mm, holodiastolic flow reversal in descending aorta

indications_for_tee: Suspected infective endocarditis with negative or non-diagnostic TTE
Pre-cardioversion for atrial fibrillation to exclude LAA thrombus

clinical_applications: Heart failure diagnosis and classification by EF and diastolic function
Valvular heart disease severity grading and timing of intervention
Hemodynamic assessment in critically ill patients
Guidance for structural interventions (TAVR, MitraClip, LAA closure)

decision_thresholds.severe_as_intervention: Symptomatic severe AS or asymptomatic with LVEF<50% or very severe (Vmax>5m/s)
decision_thresholds.severe_mr_intervention: Symptomatic severe MR or asymptomatic with LVEF ≤60% or LVESD ≥40mm
decision_thresholds.hfref_definition: LVEF ≤40% defines HFrEF requiring guideline-directed medical therapy

skos.definition: A non-invasive imaging technique using ultrasound waves to visualize cardiac structures, assess function, and evaluate hemodynamics in real-time

learning_objectives: Describe the physics of ultrasound and Doppler principles in echocardiography
Perform systematic assessment of LV size, function, and ejection fraction
Apply Doppler methods to assess valve stenosis and regurgitation severity
Evaluate diastolic function using established grading criteria
Recognize indications for TEE over TTE
Integrate echocardiographic findings with clinical decision-making
clinical_pearls: Always confirm EF by Simpson's biplane - eyeball estimates are operator-dependent
GLS may be abnormal before EF drops - useful for early chemotherapy cardiotoxicity detection
E/e' ratio >14 suggests elevated LV filling pressures (correlates with PCWP)
In atrial fibrillation, average multiple cardiac cycles for accurate measurements
TEE is far superior for LAA thrombus, prosthetic valves, and endocarditis vegetations
Low-gradient severe AS may have severe stenosis despite gradient <40mmHg if EF reduced

specialty_boards.cardiology: Critical - detailed measurement interpretation, advanced modalities, clinical integration
specialty_boards.internal_medicine: High yield - basic interpretation, clinical indications

common_misconceptions: Normal EF excludes heart failure (HFpEF has preserved EF)
Echo can accurately assess coronary artery disease (limited; stress echo detects ischemia indirectly)
All severe valvular disease requires immediate intervention (many require watchful waiting)

Assess LV function including EF and diastolic parameters
Evaluate valve disease severity using Doppler criteria
Integrate echo findings into clinical management

GLS detects subclinical dysfunction before EF falls
